Drumpa was a Barawa Kagyu monastery that was an affiliate of Baradrak Dondrubding and was home of the Drumpa Tulku, a Barawa incarnation lineage. It was established in the sixteenth century.
Kagyu Tsekchok Ling is a Barawa Kagyu monastery in Sikkim, near Gangtok. It was established in 1988 by the Seventh Kagyu Tulku as his seat in exile.
Pabyuk is a Barawa Kagyu Monastery in Sikkim that was established in the early eighteenth century by Lama Rechen Kelzang Chopel.
Zhakdra Lhatse is an important mountain in Golok. Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje had a hermitage there.
Namgyelteng is a Kadam or Nyingma monastery in Barkham.

The Tibetan Cultural Center was founded in 1979 by the Sixth Taktser Rinpoche in Bloomington, Indiana. It was renamed Tibetan Mongolian Buddhist Cultural Center in 2007 on the suggestion of His Holiness the Fourteenth Dalai Lama. It is also home to Kumbum Chamtse Ling monastery.

chinese_name: 迭亚寺, 德阳寺, 德牙寺, 代牙寺 til yag dgon,
description: Dilyak is a Karma Kagyu monastery in Nangchen.
Tsade is a Nyingma monastery in the Gonjo region, near Chamdo, that was founded in the thirteenth century by Tsade Zhanakpa Namkha Dorje.

chinese_name: 阿什当参康, 阿什旦参康, mtsha mas thog
description: Aten Tsamkhang is a Geluk monastery in Dulan County, Qinghai, that was founded around 1950.
Ke Mingyur Dorje Drak is a meditation cave in Litang. Longsel Nyingpo revealed his first treasures there in 1658: The Vajra Essence of the Three Kāyas and The Vajra Essence of the Three Roots .
Kolri is a Nyingma monastery in the Litang region that dates back to the thirteenth century. Longsel Nyingpo took over the management in the 1660s and restored it.
Geri is a place in lower Nyel. Possibly a treasure site, but Meban Rinchen Lingpa went there to study, so it must also have been a monastic institution at one time.

CIHTS, the Central Institute of Higher Tibetan Studies, was founded in 1967 by Indian Prime Minister Nehru and the Fourteenth Dalai Lama. Initially under the umbrella of Sanskit University in Varanasi, it became independent in 1977 and moved to Sarnath. In 1997 it was declared a university and the name changed to the Central University for Tibetan Studies, although it continues to use the familar anacronym CIHTS.
Tsakho is a Geluk monastery in Barkham, traditionally the capital of the Tsakho kingdom of Gyarong.
Zabulung is a Nyingma monastery in the Shang valley of Tsang, said to have been first established in the eleventh century.
Draklha Gampo is a pilgrimage site in Gyarong.
Drakkar Treldzong is a major sacred mountain in Amdo with a lengthy pilgrimage circuit. Drakkar Treldzong Monastery is one of eighteen sites along to pilgrimage route.
Kuso Togyel is a sacred mountain in Kandze, Kham.
Tashi Gomang is a Nyingma monastery in Golok that dates to the early nineteenth century.
Durpin Monastery, also known as Zang Dhok Palri Phodang, is a Nyingma monastery built by Dudjom Rinpoche in the late 1950s and early 1960s on a hill in Kalimpong, India.

Yoga Choling, known as Ghoom Monastery, is a Geluk monastery in West Bengal. It was founded in 1850 by a Mongolian lama named Sherab Gyatso. Domo Geshe ran the monastery in the early twentieth century, and constructed a large Maitreya statue there.
Dundul Rabtenling is a Nyingma monastery in Orissa, India, established by Dudjom Rinpoche in 1961. Chagdud Tulku was the first head of the monastery.

community_name: Tso Pema Orgyen Heruka Nyingmapa Gompa
wylie_name: mtsho pad+ma o rgyan he ru ka rnying ma pa dgon pa
description: Tso Pema Orgyen Heruka Nyingmapa Gompa is a Nyingma monastery on the banks of Tso Pema in Rewalsar, India. Dudjom Rinpoche established it in 1961 together with Wangdor Rinpoche.

wylie_name: o rgyan mdo sngags chos 'khor gling
description: Dudjom Gonpa, Orgyan Do-ngak Chokorling, is a Nyingma monastery in Boudhanath, Nepal. Dudjom Rinpoche built it in the early 1970s and gave the empowerments for the Dudjom Tersar there in 1977-1978. His reliquary is housed there.
Tashi Choling is a Nyingma dharma center in southern Oregon. Gyatrul Rinpoche established it in 1980.
Urgyen Samyé Chöling is a Nyingma dharma center in France. Dudjom Rinpoche established it in the late 1970s. He passed away there in 1987.
Jangsa is a Nyingma monastery in Kalimpong, India. It was controlled by the Bhutanese royal family until given to Dudjom Rinpoche in the early 1960s.
Karye was a Nyingma monastery in the Jangter, or Northern Treasure tradition, in Mangyul. During the eighteenth century it provided refuge to Polhane Sonam Tobgyel and his two sisters.

chinese_name: 桑桑拉扎寺, zang zang lha brag 'od gsal theg mchog gling
description: Zangzang Lhadrag was a monastery in the Lato region of Tsang. Rigdzin Godemchen revealed the original Northern Treasure scriptures there.
Mahasiddha Nyingmapa Center was established in Hawley, Massachusetts in 1973 by the Fourth Dodrubchen Rinpoche.
Kharnang Gongma is a Nyingma monastery that was established in 1887 on the border between Serta and Golok.
Namgyel Monastery in McCloud Ganj, Dharamsala, is the Indian branch of Namgyel Monastery in the Potala Palace, traditionally the personal monastery of the Dalai Lamas.
Nyingma Kathok Buddhist Center is a dharma center in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The Fourth Katok Getse briefly supervised teh center in the early twenty-first century.
Katok Ritrö in Pharping is a retreat center established by Chagdud Tulku in 2001.
Dudjom Namdrol Choling is a temple in Pharping, Nepal, established by Dudjom Rinpoche.
Zhichen Bairo Ling is a monastery in Boudhanath, Nepal, established by the Third Zhichen Bairo Rinpoche.
Iron Knot Ranch is a dharma center outside of Silver City, New Mexico. It was established by Chagdud Tulku some time in the late twentieth century.
Tsinta Mani Choling was a dharma center in Spokane Washington, no longer active, established by Lama Lakshey Zangpo, a disciple of Khenpo Jigme Puntsok.

Katog Tingdzin Ling is a Nyingma dharma center in Miama, Florida. It was established by Khentrul Lodrö T’hayé Rinpoche, a lama of Katok Monastery, as part of his Katog Choling network of dharma centers.
Katog Rit'hröd is a Nyingma dharma center in Parthenon, Arkansas. It was established by Khentrul Lodrö T’hayé in the early twenty-first century as part of his Katog Choling network of dharma centers.
Sravasti Abbey is a dharma center in the Geluk tradition in Washington State. It was established in 2003 by Ven. Thubten Chodron.
Orgyen Dorje Den is a Nyingma dharma center established in Alameda, California, by Gyatrul Rinpoche.
Palri Pema Od Ling is a Nyingma dharma center established by Penor Rinpoche in Austin, Texas.
Kathok Tibetan Buddhist Meditation Centre is a Nyingma dharma center in Coombs, British Columbia. It was established by Lingtrul Rinpoche.
Katog Ratna Ling is a Nyingma dharma center in Lafayette, Louisianna. It was established in 2004 by Khentrul Lodrö Thaye Rinpoche as part of his Katog Choling network of dharma centers.

wylie_name: a 'dzom 'od gsal mdo sngags chos 'khor gling
description: Adzom Wosel Dongag Chokher Ling is the main branch of Adzom Monastery outside of Tibet. It was established in Pharping, Nepal, by Azom Jurmey Jamtso Rinpoche.
Yeshe Khorlo Buddhist Society is a Nyingma dharma center in Singapore, a branch of the Yeshe Nyingpo network established by Gangteng Tulku.
Doko is a Sakya monastery in Pelyul. It was established by Pakpa in the thirteenth century.

Tsegyalgar East, in Conway, Massachusetts, was the first Dzogchen Community center established by Namkhai Norbu in North America, in 1982. It maintains an associated retreat center, Khandroling, on 220 acres in Buckland Massachusetts.

Samten Tse was a nunnery at Tsurpu. It was established in the mid-twentieth century by Orgyen Tsomo, known as the Great Ḍākinī of Tsurpu. Although it survived the initial Communist takeover of Tibet, it appears to have been completely destroyed during the Cultural Revolution. It was reestablished in India under the guidance of Khandro Rinpoche.
Drukto is a Nyingma monastery in Nyarong, a branch of Katok, that dates to the twelfth century.

Yachen Gar is a modern community of Tibetan practitioners. primarily female, in Pelyul county founded by Khenpo Akhyuk in 1985. It is said to have once housed 10,000 individuals. In 2019 it was significantly reduced in size by order of the Chinese government.

wylie_name: bla brang bkra shis 'khyil rgyud pa grwa tshang
description: The Tantric College of Labrang Tashikhyil has two branches, the Lower, established by Jamyang Zhepa in 1719, and the Upper, established in 1943 by the Fifth Jamyang Zhepa.
Gotsa, a Geluk monastery in Kham, was founded in 1182 by Gotsa Kunga Jampa Gyeltsen.
Dzamling Gar is the international headquarters of Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche's Dzochen Community.
Merigar is the Italian seat of Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche's Dzogchen Community. He established it in 1981.

The Dratsang Lhentsok, or Central Monastic Body, is the governing authority of the Drukpa Kagyu tradition of Bhutan. The head of the Central Monastic Body is the Je Khenpo. It is located in either Tashichoedzong or Punakha, depending on the season.

The Chentsel School was a modern Buddhist educational institution in Shigatse established in 1956 by the Tenth Paṇchen Lama. He initially placed it in the Kunsik Palace where a school named Tse Nyiwo Zimchung had recently closed. The initial name was Nyiwo School. It moved to Kyikyi Nakhar in 1958. Three hundred young men, both lay and monastics, were in the first class. The curriculum, designed to train young men for the modern period, included language instruction in Tibetan, Chinese, and Hindi, and military arts.
Mewa Dargye Jamchen Chokhorling is the largest Nyingma monastery in Ngawa. It was established in 1646. The First Dodrubchen Rinpoche instituted the Longchen Nyingtik there in the nineteenth century.
Lung-ngon is a Nyingma monastery in Golok that was established in 1958 by the Tenth Paṇchen Lama.
The Zurkhardo stūpas, said to have been constructed by Śāntarakṣita, mark the place that the Tibetan king Tri Songdetsen first met and prostrated to Padmasambhava.
Go-ngon was a monastery established in the seventh century and converted to the Kadam tradition in the twelfth century.
